docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bloomberg, Heckled, Presses Smoking Curbs'' (front page, Oct. 11): Smokers demand their right to smoke while, probably, with the same gasping breath, they complain about the rising cost of health care.

headline.main: Free to Smoke, Forced to Cough

docs.abstract: Letter from Peter Zimmer says smokers have right to smoke, but it should not be on nonsmoker's health care dime (Oct 11 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Bloomberg, Heckled, Presses Smoking Curbs'' (front page, Oct. 11):     Smokers demand their right to smoke while, probably, with the same gasping breath, they complain about the rising cost of health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Jim Hodges positively glowed the other day as he and BMW executives announced a $400 million investment in an auto production line near Greenville, where 400 more workers will soon be hired to turn out Z4 roadsters, at wages twice the state's average. But the state's largest newspaper greeted the news by somberly noting that BMW alone could not stanch the flow of jobs from South Carolina. When it comes to the economy in this election season, it seems that no news is good news for governors. Mr. Hodges, a Democrat who leapt into office from the Legislature in 1998 by thumping a weak incumbent, knows this all too well.

headline.main: Economy Lurks Over the Races For Governor

docs.abstract: South Carolina's governor's race, too close to call almost from start, is one of several extremely competitive races shadowed by voters' worries about economy; contest is between incumbent Democratic Governor Jim Hodges and Republican opponent Mark Sanford; incumbents or chosen successors are being held responsible for stalled economy and kept on defensive about its consequences, namely, budget deficits, squeezed spending for social services and looming tax increases; governors of both parties in several states are facing kinds of questions about pocketbook issues that candidates in Congressional races have been largely able to avoid; only 16 incumbent governors are seeking re-election in November, out of 36 races nationwide; while Republicans in several states are enjoying double-digit leads, handful of Democratic incumbents are having more difficulty; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Rumsfeld War Guidelines Call for Early Action Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, in a personal set of guidelines for committing forces to combat, wrote that leaders must quickly judge when diplomacy has failed, then ''act forcefully, early, during the pre-crisis period'' to foil an attack on the nation. A1 Bali Death Toll Rises The death toll in the car bombing in Bali, Indonesia, climbed to at least 184, including at least 2 Americans. A dozen of the 300 injured survivors were in critical condition and another 30 bodies were believed to be buried in the rubble. The attacks were being attributed to Indonesian terrorists, possibly linked to Al Qaeda or other Islamic extremists. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Large amounts of federal money intended to provide health insurance to children are going unused, federal officials say, even though 8.5 million children are uninsured. On Oct. 1, states lost $1.2 billion that had been appropriated by Congress to provide health coverage for low-income children. The money, unclaimed after four years, reverted to the Treasury and can now be used for other purposes -- anything, including law enforcement, military pay, farm subsidies or the fight against terrorism.

headline.main: States Forfeit Unspent U.S. Money for Child Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Federal officials say large amounts of federal money intended to provide health insurance to children are going unused, even though 8.5 million children are uninsured; states lost $1.2 billion on October 1 that was appropriated by Congress to provide health coverage for low-income children; money, unclaimed after four years, reverted to Treasury and can be now used for other purposes; federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services administrator Thomas A Scully is optimistic Congress will pass legislation to restore money to Children's Health Insurance Program (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the debate yesterday among the candidates for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. The participants were H. Carl McCall, Democratic Party; Gerard J. Cronin, Right to Life Party; George E. Pataki, Republican Party; Thomas K. Leighton, Marijuana Reform Party; Scott Jeffrey, Libertarian Party; Stanley Aronowitz, Green Party; and Tom Golisano, Independence Party. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/nyregion. Taxes Q. -- . . . Can you promise right now that there will not be a tax increase next year if elected?

docs.lead_paragraph: As a senior executive of Aetna U.S. Healthcare, Dr. Arthur Leibowitz used to offer doctors a choice: our way or the highway. Now, in a surprising switch of a sort more common among lawyers than doctors, he is using his insider's knowledge on the other side of the table. He helps doctors, patients and employers get through managed care's minefields in his role as executive vice president of Health Advocate Inc., a start-up based in West Conshohocken, Pa., outside Philadelphia.

headline.main: Private Sector; Health Care, From Both Sides Now

docs.abstract: Dr Arthur Leibowitz, executive vice president of Health Advocate Inc, helps doctors, patients and employers maximize benefits of managed healthcare; is former senior executive of Aetna US Healthcare, where he worked other side of fence (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is something rather God-like about ordaining a body of water to appear on your land. And in creating an Eden-like garden setting where plants and animals will thrive. Whether it is a God complex or just good old home-improvement obsession, the craze over garden ponds in the county continues unabated. The pond industry reports a climb in the numbers of homeowners putting in water gardens, defying logical obstacles like drought, West Nile virus warnings and economic downturns.
docs.abstract: Article on continuing craze over garden ponds in US focuses on Westchester County, NY; aquatic nurseries and installers report sharp increase in pond business over last year; pond owners comment; tips on planning and installing ponds; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gabriela Schwed and Robert Underhill were married last evening at Loft Eleven, a party space in New York, where Judge Sidney H. Stein of the United States District Court in New York officiated. Ms. Schwed, 35, is keeping her name. She works in New York for the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, where she is the manager of international reproductive-health projects. She graduated from Clark University in Worcester, Mass., was a Peace Corps volunteer in the Dominican Republic from 1991 to 1993, and later received a master's degree in public health from Columbia. She is the daughter of Annette and Pedro Schwed of New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Re ''Balancing the Budget on the Backs of Elderly,'' Sept. 29: Having seen my aunt's house sold to pay the expense of her nursing home, and having visited patients at A. Holly Paterson and private nursing homes, and having explored insurance for long-term care for myself, I was surprised to learn that some lucky old folks were living at home with round-the-clock health care and that Nassau residents are paying for it. The distribution of resources to the elderly has been fraught with inequity from the beginning: those lucky enough to be housed in A. Holly Paterson usually had some pull, either personal or political. The rest of the elderly infirm had to make their own arrangements.
docs.abstract: Susan Risberg letter on September 29 article questions why some elderly residents of Nassau County, NY, are provided additional funds to live in private nursing homes or at home with round-the-clock health care while others are not

docs.lead_paragraph: IN two conferences last month sponsored by local law firms, panelists from the fields of accounting, corporate law and insurance warned that the effects of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, passed by Congress on July 30 in response to the wave of corporate ethics scandals that have shaken the stock market, will be far-ranging and transforming. The conferences, both in Melville, were sponsored by Ruskin Moscou Faltischek and by Farrell Fritz, two of Long Island's largest law firms. The meetings provided what was for many participants the first in-depth exposure to legislation that is widely expected to change the way publicly traded companies handle matters ranging from internal accounting to corporate governance.

headline.main: Coping With New Federal Corporate Ethics Law

docs.abstract: Panelists addressing two conferences, both in Melville, sponsored by local law firms of Ruskin Moscou Faltischek and Farrell Fritz, warn that effects of Sarbanes-Oxley Act will be far-reaching; legislation was passed by Congress in July in response to wave of corporate ethics scandals; conferences focus on implementing new procedures to avoid possible criminal investigations; photo (M)
